body:
This is indeed a _bug_. 

Thanks for raising the issue!

Thanks for raising the issue, @LiamClark!

I think this actually demonstrates multiple problems:

1. While the Jupiter engine logs a warning when it gets a `ClassSelector` for an abstract class, the Vintage engine blindly tries to run it and, unsurprisingly, fails.
1. The Surefire provider currently is unable to determine whether a class is executable as a test from the `TestPlan` it gets from the `Launcher`.

While we're discussing how to solve (2), I think the proper behavior for (1) is pretty clear: The Vintage engine should apply the same predicate it uses for classpath scanning (`IsPotentialJUnit4TestClass`) to the result of discovery. From a brief look on the code, I think filtering the classes inside `TestClassCollector` in `JUnit4DiscoveryRequestResolver` and logging warnings for those that were excluded should work.

---

There may be an additional issue. When I copy the two classes into the sample Gradle consumer and delete all other test classes, the test is discovered and executed:

```
Test run finished after 10068 ms
[         3 containers found      ]
[         0 containers skipped    ]
[         3 containers started    ]
[         0 containers aborted    ]
[         3 containers successful ]
[         0 containers failed     ]
[         1 tests found           ]
[         0 tests skipped         ]
[         1 tests started         ]
[         0 tests aborted         ]
[         1 tests successful      ]
[         0 tests failed          ]
```

From `build/test-results/junit-platform/TEST-junit-vintage.xml`:

```xml
<testcase name="test" classname="com.example.project.SubBugTest" time="0.001">
<system-out><![CDATA[
unique-id: [engine:junit-vintage]/[runner:com.example.project.SubBugTest]/[test:test(com.example.project.SubBugTest)]
display-name: test
]]></system-out>
</testcase>
```

Did you also use M4? Something must be different in your setup. Can you provide more details or, if possible, share the project?
@marcphilipp I forked the sample project and added the classes there, it still shows the same behaviour for me. It's located here https://github.com/LiamClark/junit5-samples

Ah, `SubBugTest` isn't `public` in your project and thus not excluded when scanning the classpath. So, I think we can forget about that issue.

Do you want to give fixing (1) a shot?

@marcphilipp I must have removed the public when I tried maven with jupiter, my bad!

I just opened #776 as my attempt for fixing (1)

rename.from: Abstract test classes mis-behaving in JUnit-vintage
rename.to: VintageTestEngine attempts to execute abstract test classes

body: FYI: updated _Deliverables_ and formatted example output.

> I just opened #776 as my attempt for fixing (1)

If you had referred to this issue in the commit message for your PR, you wouldn't have to explicitly state that since GitHub would do it for you. ðŸ˜‰

> Reopening to address Surefire issue.

Out of curiosity, which issue are you referring to?
> The Surefire provider currently is unable to determine whether a class is executable as a test from the `TestPlan` it gets from the `Launcher`.
Don't you think we should address the Surefire issue in a different, dedicated ticket?
You're right. I just wanted to keep this ticket open as a reminder to create the dedicated ticket. ðŸ˜‰
